de.hu.gralog.algorithm
Interface Algorithm

All Superinterfaces:
Serializable
public interface Algorithm
extends Serializable

This interface has to be implement by all GrALoG-Algorithms. An algorithm in GrALoG is a JavaBean with an execute-function defined by this interface. Please see de.hu.gralog.beans for a general introduction to JavaBeans and further references.

Plugin-Developers

Lets suppose you want to implement an algorithm which takes two parameters:
  • a parameter counter which should be a positive integer
  • a required parameter structure, whose underlying JGraphT-Graph should be a SimpleDirectedGraph whose vertices extend LabeledStructureVertex and whose edges extend DefaultEdge.

The first thing you have to do is to implement your Algorithm-Class which should look something like this: 

 public class YourAlgorithm<V extends LabeledStructureVertex, E extends DefaultEdge, G extends DirectedGraph<V, E>>
                implements Algorithm {
 
        private int counter;
 
        private Structure<V, E, ?, G> structure;
 
        public void setCounter(int counter) {
                this.counter = counter;
        }
 
        public int getCounter() {
                return counter;
        }
 
        public void setStructure(Structure<V, E, ?, G> structure) {
                this.structure = structure;
        }
 
        public Structure<V, E, ?, G> getStructure() {
                return structure;
        }
 
        public AlgorithmResult execute() throws InvalidPropertyValuesException,
                        UserException {
                InvalidPropertyValuesException e = new InvalidPropertyValuesException();
 
                if (getStructure() == null)
                        e.addPropertyError("structure",
                                        InvalidPropertyValuesException.PROPERTY_REQUIRED);
                if (getCounter() <= 0)
                        e.addPropertyError("counter",
                                        InvalidPropertyValuesException.GREATER_ZERO);
                if (e.hasErrors())
                        throw e;
 
                // do something and build result
                return result;
        }
 }

As you can see each parameter is reflected as a member variable of YourAlgorithm. Furthermore there are two functions for each parameter which are called getter and setter ( the naming convention for these functions comes from the JavaBeans-Specification ). Since there is a getter and a setter for each parameter, GrALoG knows that YourAlgorithm takes two parameters: counter and structure. Before the user executes YourAlgorithm GrALoG allows the user to edit these parameters, so when execute is called you can suppose that all parameters are set according to the users opinion.

As we have said there are restrictions on the parameters. So the first thing you should do is to check for these restrictions in your execute-method. In this case it is checked whether structure is not equal to null and counter is creater than zero and if not an InvalidPropertyValuesException is thrown which gives the user the possibility to alter his input.

The next step is to define a BeanInfo for YourAlgorithm. The easiest way to do this is to define a class YourAlgorithmBeanInfo - the naming convention again comes from JavaBean - in the same package as YourAlgorithm, which should look like this: 

        public class YourAlgorithmBeanInfo extends SimpleBeanInfo {
     
                private static final BeanDescriptor BEAN_DESCRIPTOR = new BeanDescriptor( YourAlgorithm.class );
                private static final PropertyDescriptor[] PROPERTY_DESCRIPTORS = new PropertyDescriptor[2];
     
                static {
                        BEAN_DESCRIPTOR.setDisplayName( "A name for YourAlgorithm" );
                        BEAN_DESCRIPTOR.setShortDescription( 
                                        "A description for your algorithm in html." );
    
                        try {
                                PROPERTY_DESCRIPTORS[0] = new PropertyDescriptor( "counter", YourAlgorithm.class );
                                PROPERTY_DESCRIPTORS[0].setShortDescription( "A description for the property counter." );
                                PROPERTY_DESCRIPTORS[1] = new ChooseStructurePropertyDescriptor( "structure", YourAlgorithm.class, new LabeledSimpleDirectedStructureTypeInfo() );
                                PROPERTY_DESCRIPTORS[1].setShortDescription( "A description for the property structure." );
                        } catch( IntrospectionException e ) {
                                e.printStackTrace();
                        }
    
                        public BeanDescriptor getBeanDescriptor() {
                                return BEAN_DESCRIPTOR;
                        }
    
                        public PropertyDescriptor[] getPropertyDescriptors() {
                                return PROPERTY_DESCRIPTORS;
                        }
        }

YourAlgorithmBeanInfo basically defines a so called BeanDescriptor and an array of PropertyDescriptor one for each parameter. The BeanDescriptor describes properties of the algorithm such as a name and a description in html. Each PropertyDescriptor describes a property of your Algorithm. This algorithm uses two PropertyDescriptors - a more detailed introduction to propertydescriptors and the avaible types of propertydescriptors can be found in de.hu.gralog.beans.propertydescriptor. It follows a short introduction to the descriptors used in our example:

Class Description
PropertyDescriptor This PropertyDescriptors should be used for all basic types like boolean, int, double, String .. . It offers a standard editor for these types.
ChooseStructurePropertyDescriptor This PropertyDescriptor should be used whenever you want the user to choose one of the currently opened structures in GrALoG. It allows to filter those which are of a certain type - in the example of the type LabeledSimpleDirectedStructure.

The last thing you have to do in your algorithm ( after making your calculations ) is to return an AlgorithmResult. Please refer to the documentation of AlgorithmResult how to do this.

Author:
Sebastian Ordyniak

Method Summary
 AlgorithmResult execute()
          This function is called when all parameters have been set by the user.
 

Method Detail

execute

AlgorithmResult execute()
                        throws InvalidPropertyValuesException,
                               UserException
This function is called when all parameters have been set by the user. It returns an AlgorithmResult which describes the output of your algorithm.

Returns:
it is possible to return null, which tells GrALoG not to display anything. This can be useful when your Algorithm only wants to manipulate a GrALoG-Structure but does not need to show a result.
Throws:
InvalidPropertyValuesException - should be thrown if not all parameters where set correctly
UserException - should be thrown if an error occurs during your calculations and you know what went wrong
